title: SEC Charges Sam Bankman-Fried With Defrauding Investors
content:encoded:
Less than a day after Bahamian authorities arrested Sam Bankman-Fried, the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has slapped the fallen FTX founder with its own charges.

â€œThe [SEC] today charged Bankman-Fried with orchestrating a scheme to defraud equity investors in [FTX], the crypto trading platform of which he was the CEO and co-founder,â€ the agency said in a statement.

â€œInvestigations as to other securities law violations and into other entities and persons relating to the alleged misconduct are ongoing.â€

SEC regulators say FTX under Bankman-Fried raised more than $1.8 billion from equity investors since May 2019 â€” with more than $1.1 billion of those funds coming from roughly 90 US-based investors.

Bankman-Fried promoted FTX as a safe and responsible crypto exchange, the SEC said, â€œspecifically, touting FTXâ€™s sophisticated, automated risk measures to protect customer assets. 

The complaint alleges that Bankman-Fried exacted a years-long fraud to conceal from FTX investors three major points:

  • diversion of FTX user funds to his trading unit Alameda Research,
  • special treatment afforded to Alameda on the FTX platform â€” including a virtually unlimited â€œline of creditâ€ funded by the platformâ€™s customers,
  • increased risk due to FTXâ€™s exposure to Alamedaâ€™s significant foldings of â€œovervalued, illiquid assets such as FTX-affiliated tokens.â€

â€œThe complaint further alleges that Bankman-Fried used commingled FTX customersâ€™ funds at Alameda to make undisclosed venture investments, lavish real estate purchases, and large political donations,â€ the SEC said.

The SEC has charged Bankman-Fried with violating anti-fraud provisions, and seeks injunctions including one that prohibits him from handling securities professionally, disgorgement, civil penalties, and a bar from serving as an officer or director of a company moving forward.

Additional, parallel charges have also been filed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) and the US Attorneyâ€™s Office for the Southern District of New York, per the statement.

Calls for Bankman-Fried to face legal action for his alleged wrongdoing have echoed across the crypto space since FTX suddenly went belly up last month. 

Now, those pleas are finally being met.

Get the dayâ€™s top crypto news and insights delivered to your inbox every evening. Subscribe to Blockworksâ€™ free newsletter now.


Can’t wait? Get our news the fastest way possible. Join us on Telegram.

creator: Samyuktha Sriram
title: Binance Withdrawals Exceed $900M in 24 Hours: Report
content:encoded:
Crypto exchange Binance saw massive outflows from its platform on Monday following a confusing statement regarding the state of the colossal exchangeâ€™s reserves.

Data from Nansen reported by CoinDesk on Monday shows that Binance recorded $902 million worth of outflows over 24 hours, exceeding all other centralized exchanges over the same period. The outflows from Binance were nearly nine times as large as the second largest outflow seen on the day.

The withdrawals may have stemmed from concerns over the state of the exchangeâ€™s solvency, with many calling into question Binanceâ€™s â€œProof-of-Reservesâ€ statement released last week. A number of exchanges have been issuing similar statements as they aim to shore up user trust in the wake of the FTX exchangeâ€™s collapse last month. Binanceâ€™s statement, however, drew criticism for its failure to include any liabilities.Â 

Why get an attestation from an accounting firm and only show assets but not liabilities? This accounting should be trivial.

Why call it an audit, when the audit firm states it is not?

You state you have no liabilities with counterparties. What about against your own books?

— Dylan LeClair (@DylanLeClair_) December 12, 2022

Binanceâ€™s outflows werenâ€™t exclusively dominated by retail investors. Nansenâ€™s Andrew Thurman shared data showing large redemptions made by market makers as well. Jump Crypto withdrew $146 million from Binance over the last week, while Wintermute pulled $300 million in a single day.

â€œNormally Jump has massive inflows/outflows to exchanges This time is different — Jump has redeemed $245 million in BUSD on the month, $106 million in the past week, and $30 million in the past 24 hours,â€ said Thurman in a tweet.

In his view, Jump looked to be â€œworking very hard to cash out & not get burned again.â€

While the scale of outflows would normally be concerning from a liquidity perspective, crypto market analysts were largely unfazed by Mondayâ€™s withdrawals. Conor Ryder, a research analyst from market data provider Kaiko, commented that the depth of Binanceâ€™s Bitcoin order book was largely unchanged.

Definitely one to keep an eye on, but so far no change in BTC liquidity on Binance, despite withdrawals from some of the biggest market makers https://t.co/qru2YbP35K pic.twitter.com/UnGzEKWRPW

— Conor Ryder (@ConorRyder) December 12, 2022

These sentiments were echoed by analysts at blockchain data platform Arkham Intelligence, who told CoinDesk that the outflow â€œdoesnâ€™t seem notably anomalousâ€ considering Binance appears to hold $64 billion worth of assets.

The post Binance Withdrawals Exceed $900M in 24 Hours: Report appeared first on Unchained Podcast.

creator: Samyuktha Sriram
title: Crypto Exchange Binance Faces U.S. Justice Department Probe: Report
content:encoded:
The US Department of Justice is investigating Binance, the worldâ€™s largest crypto exchange, for allegedly facilitating illicit transfers on its platform, according to a Reuters report on Monday.

The report, citing four people with knowledge of the matter, details how U.S. prosecutors are considering bringing criminal charges against individual Binance executives, including its CEO Changpeng Zhao.

The investigation reportedly began in 2018 when the U.S. Attorneyâ€™s office in Seattle began looking into a series of illicit transfers made by criminals through Binance. According to Reutersâ€™ sources, DOJ prosecutors are split between filing a criminal case, as some believe more evidence needs to be gathered before bringing the allegations to light.

A Binance spokesperson responded to the Reuters report, saying that the publication â€œhas it wrong again,â€ stressing the exchangeâ€™s focus on compliance with anti-money-laundering rules.Â Â Â 

Reuters has it wrong again.

Now they're attacking our incredible law enforcement team. A team that we're incredibly proud of – they've made crypto more secure for all of us.

Hereâ€™s the full statement we sent the reporter and a blog about our remarkable law enforcement team.

— Binance (@binance) December 12, 2022

In a blog post on Monday, Tigran Gambaryan, Binanceâ€™s global head of intelligence and investigations, said the crypto exchange had responded to over 47,000 requests from law enforcement since November 2021.

Gambaryan, who served as a special agent at the IRSâ€™s cyber crimes unit for a decade before joining Binance, said the firm had increased its security and compliance headcount by 500% in this year alone.

â€œLet this be known to the naysayers and aspiring criminals: crypto is not the criminal tool the media often makes it out to be,â€ he said in a statement.

The post Crypto Exchange Binance Faces U.S. Justice Department Probe: Report appeared first on Unchained Podcast.

creator: Cointelegraph By  Prashant Jha
title: SEC charges FTX CEO SBF for defrauding investors a day after his arrest
dc:creator: Cointelegraph By  Prashant Jha
content: SEC has filed charges against the former CEO Sam Bankman-Fried, accusing him of defrauding U.S. customers and concealing the diversion of customers' funds.
contentSnippet: SEC has filed charges against the former CEO Sam Bankman-Fried, accusing him of defrauding U.S. customers and concealing the diversion of customers' funds.

creator: Samyuktha Sriram
title: New FTX CEOâ€™s Testimony: User Funds Were Commingled With Alameda Assets
content:encoded:
The veteran lawyer overseeing defunct crypto exchange FTXâ€™s ongoing bankruptcy proceedings will soon offer potentially damning testimony against the exchangeâ€™s former chief, Sam Bankman-Fried.Â 

In testimony published on Monday, recently appointed FTX CEO John J Ray III, who oversaw the bankruptcy of Enron in the early 2000s, made it clear that Bankman-Fried mixed customer and corporate funds despite claims to the contrary.

â€œFirst, customer assets from FTX.com were commingled with assets from the Alameda trading platform,â€ said Ray. Alameda used these funds to engage in margin trading, exposing them to â€œmassive losses,â€ he added.

Rayâ€™s testimony could have far reaching implications for any legal defense that Bankman-Fried hopes to make. The FTX founder and former CEO has portrayedâ€” and planned to portray in now-scrapped Congressional testimony, a transcript of which was obtained by Forbesâ€”an image of negligence in managing FTXâ€™s affairs, claiming on more than one occasion that he â€œdidnâ€™t knowingly commingleâ€ FTX user funds with his trading firm Alameda Research.Â 

As of Monday, Bankman-Fried is now in custody and awaiting extradition by US authorities, which means his own testimony could come soon. That could cause him difficulty, according to industry watcher Nic Carter, a general partner at Castle Island Ventures who said on Monday that Bankman-Fried would likely be â€œhamstrungâ€ by Rayâ€™s testimony, which will come before his own and put him on the back foot.Â Â 

â€œHe goes first, and he is contradicting everything Sam is going to say, and John Ray wouldn’t perjure himself, so it means Sam won’t be able to say anything without perjuring himself,â€ Carter wrote.Â 

because he goes first, and he is contradicting everything Sam is going to say, and John Ray wouldn't perjure himself, so it means Sam won't be able to say anything without perjuring himself.

— GPT-nic (@nic__carter) December 12, 2022

Rayâ€™s testimony will also likely be damaging for a number of other FTX executives involved in the exchangeâ€™s collapse.Â 

Ray disclosed a â€œspending bingeâ€ by the FTX Group between 2021 and 2022 in which the entity spent $5 billion on businesses and investmentsâ€“most of which were not worth nearly as much as the amount for which they were acquired. The group also disbursed over $1 billion worth of loans to FTX insiders, the testimony said.

He also revealed that FTX US was not, in fact, operated independently of FTX.com. This directly contradicts Bankman-Friedâ€™s consistent claims to the contrary and that FTX US was a separate legal entity. In a Dec. 1 tweet, Bankman-Fried had said he was fairly sure that FTX US was solvent and all customers could be made whole.

â€œI’m not sure why US withdrawals were turned off,â€ said Bankman-Fried at the time.

The post New FTX CEOâ€™s Testimony: User Funds Were Commingled With Alameda Assets appeared first on Unchained Podcast.

creator: Samyuktha Sriram
title: Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried Arrested Amid US Indictment
content:encoded:
Authorities in the Bahamas on Monday evening arrested Sam Bankman-Fried, the former CEO of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange which fell to earth with a bang last month, costing users and creditors billions of dollars and cratering large swaths of the crypto market.Â Â 

The Royal Bahamas Police Force took Bankman-Fried into custody following a formal request made by U.S. authorities, which has asked the Bahamian government to extradite the former CEO and on Tuesday issued a formal complaint detailing a number of criminal charges including wire fraud, wire fraud conspiracy, securities fraud, securities fraud conspiracy and money laundering.Â 

â€œThe Bahamas and the United States have a shared interest in holding accountable all individuals associated with FTX who may have betrayed the public trust and broken the law,â€ said Bahamian Prime Minister Philip Davis in a statement.

The Bahamas also plans to continue looking into potential criminal misconduct involved in the collapse of FTX and its related entities alongside the U.S. run investigation.Â 

The exchange and its founder had been based in the Caribbean country due to its favorable stance toward crypto companies, which became a source of contention amid rumors of close ties between Bankman-Fried and the archipelagoâ€™s chief regulator.Â 

Bankman-Friedâ€™s arrest was also confirmed by the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, which on Tuesday morning published an indictment painting Bankman-Friedâ€™s actions in stark terms.Â 

â€œThroughout this period, Bankman-Fried portrayed himself as a responsible leader of the crypto communityâ€ and â€œtouted the importance of regulation and accountability,â€ the complaint said. â€œCustomers around the world believed his lies, and sent billions of dollars to FTX, believing their assets were secure on the FTX trading platform.â€Â 

â€œBut from the start,â€ the complaint added, â€œBankman-Fried improperly diverted customer assets to his privately-held crypto hedge fund, Alameda Research LLC and then used those customer funds to make undisclosed venture investments, lavish real estate purchases, and large political donations.â€

USA Damian Williams: Earlier this evening, Bahamian authorities arrested Samuel Bankman-Fried at the request of the U.S. Government, based on a sealed indictment filed by the SDNY. We expect to move to unseal the indictment in the morning and will have more to say at that time.

— US Attorney SDNY (@SDNYnews) December 12, 2022

Bankman-Friedâ€™s arrest and indictment come after weeks of speculation and righteous indignation over a perceived lack of effort to detain the disgraced founder after his exchange collapsed in spectacular fashion mid November. Many in the crypto world were especially bemused by Bankman-Friedâ€™s apparent freedom to embark on a lengthy media tour in which he retailed his preferred version of events to countless news outlets, against the advice of his legal team.Â 

FTX collapsed in mid-November after it emerged that its sister firm, the trading company Alameda Research, had been gambling with customer funds to fill a vast hole on its balance sheet. That left wafer-thin collateral backing user deposits, which proved insufficient when FTX subsequently suffered a run on customer deposits.Â 

FTX was soon forced to declare bankruptcy, and the ensuing hunt for Alamedaâ€™s lost billions shed light on a number of shady practices at the heart of an exchange whose founder had weeks prior been featured in front cover splashes by the likes of Fortune Magazine as the face of the crypto industryâ€™s respectable side. Contagion followed quickly, bringing down a host of companies to which Bankman-Fried had extended bailout loans earlier in the year while casting himself as a white knight.Â 

Hours before his arrest on Monday Bankman-Fried appears to have tweeted the latest in a line of ad hoc defenses,Â  responding to an article that claimed his FTX inner circle operated a secret Signal group called â€œWirefraudâ€ to discuss operations that were kept under wraps.

â€œIf this is true then I wasn’t a member of that inner circle. (I’m quite sure it’s just false; I have never heard of such a group),â€ tweeted Bankman-Fried, around two hours before authorities released a statement confirming his arrest.

The post Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried Arrested Amid US Indictment appeared first on Unchained Podcast.

â€œThroughout this period, Bankman-Fried portrayed himself as a responsible leader of the crypto communityâ€ and â€œtouted the importance of regulation and accountability,â€ the complaint said. â€œCustomers around the world believed his lies, and sent billions of dollars to FTX, believing their assets were secure on the FTX trading platform.â€Â 
â€œBut from the start,â€ the complaint added, â€œBankman-Fried improperly diverted customer assets to his privately-held crypto hedge fund, Alameda Research LLC and then used those customer funds to make undisclosed venture investments, lavish real estate purchases, and large political donations.â€
USA Damian Williams: Earlier this evening, Bahamian authorities arrested Samuel Bankman-Fried at the request of the U.S. Government, based on a sealed indictment filed by the SDNY.  We expect to move to unseal the indictment in the morning and will have more to say at that time.
â€” US Attorney SDNY (@SDNYnews) December 12, 2022


Bankman-Friedâ€™s arrest and indictment come after weeks of speculation and righteous indignation over a perceived lack of effort to detain the disgraced founder after his exchange collapsed in spectacular fashion mid November. Many in the crypto world were especially bemused by Bankman-Friedâ€™s apparent freedom to embark on a lengthy media tour in which he retailed his preferred version of events to countless news outlets, against the advice of his legal team.Â 
FTX collapsed in mid-November after it emerged that its sister firm, the trading company Alameda Research, had been gambling with customer funds to fill a vast hole on its balance sheet. That left wafer-thin collateral backing user deposits, which proved insufficient when FTX subsequently suffered a run on customer deposits.Â 
FTX was soon forced to declare bankruptcy, and the ensuing hunt for Alamedaâ€™s lost billions shed light on a number of shady practices at the heart of an exchange whose founder had weeks prior been featured in front cover splashes by the likes of Fortune Magazine as the face of the crypto industryâ€™s respectable side. Contagion followed quickly, bringing down a host of companies to which Bankman-Fried had extended bailout loans earlier in the year while casting himself as a white knight.Â 
Hours before his arrest on Monday Bankman-Fried appears to have tweeted the latest in a line of ad hoc defenses,Â  responding to an article that claimed his FTX inner circle operated a secret Signal group called â€œWirefraudâ€ to discuss operations that were kept under wraps.
â€œIf this is true then I wasnâ€™t a member of that inner circle. (Iâ€™m quite sure itâ€™s just false; I have never heard of such a group),â€ tweeted Bankman-Fried, around two hours before authorities released a statement confirming his arrest.
The post Former FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried Arrested Amid US Indictment appeared first on Unchained Podcast.
